titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edward Eberstadt & Sons Records
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The records document the business activity of Edward Eberstadt and include records from three of his firms: Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons. While some material dates to Eberstadt's early years in business, most of the collection documents Eberstadt's business relationship with William Robertson Coe (Eberstadt was Coe's agent), and the formation of the Coe Collection of Western Americana. Records include financial records, acquisition records, correspondence between Eberstadt and Coe and between Eberstadt and other dealers, and descriptions of rare books and manuscripts, including some transcripts of manuscripts.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Thomas W. Streeter collection of Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons catalogs (WA MSS S-2588). Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Edward Eberstadt, 1959, and of Charles F. Eberstadt, 1974.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Edward Eberstadt & Sons Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edward Eberstadt & Sons Records. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection was partially processed in 2011. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call numbers: Uncat WA MS Coe, Uncat WA MS Eberstadt

bioghist.head: Edward Eberstadt & Sons
bioghist.p: Edward Eberstadt & Sons was a bookselling business in New York City, specializing in rare books and manuscripts related to the history of the American West. The business was started by Edward Eberstadt (1883-1958) as The Latin American Book Company, and later the Hudson Book Company in Tarrytown, NY, circa 1910, specializing in Latin Americana. The business later became Edward Eberstadt and, finally, Edward Eberstadt & Sons. Edward's sons Charles and Lindley Eberstadt joined the firm in the late 1930s and continued the business until Charles's death in 1974 and Lindley's death in 1985.

bioghist.head: William Robertson Coe (1869-1955)
bioghist.p: William Robertson Coe was born in Staffordshire, England, and immigrated to Pennsylvania at the age of 14. He began working in the insurance business soon thereafter, and by 1910 had risen to become the president of Johnson and Higgins Insurance Co. He was among the foremost collectors of Western Americana in the early twentieth century, and his gifts of rare books and manuscripts became the foundation of the Yale Collection of Western Americana at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records document the business activity of Edward Eberstadt and include records from three of his firms: Hudson Book Company, Edward Eberstadt, and Edward Eberstadt & Sons. While some material dates to Eberstadt's early years in business, most of the collection documents Eberstadt's business relationship with William Robertson Coe (Eberstadt was Coe's agent), and the formation of the Coe Collection of Western Americana, which was donated to Yale in the 1940s. Records include financial records, acquisition records, correspondence between Eberstadt and Coe and between Eberstadt and other dealers, and descriptions of rare books and manuscripts, including some transcripts of manuscripts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Financial Records, 1910-1945. II. Correspondence, 1920-1954. III. Appraisal Records, 1943-1953. IV. Acquisition Files, circa 1920-circa 1950. V. Catalog Files, 1942-1951, undated. VI. Other Papers, 1930-1945.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Accounting Records and Coe Collection Bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of records relating to the purchase of rare books and manuscripts, and to business expenses, and bills to William R. Coe for acquisitions on his behalf.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: General Correspondence (Chronological) and General Correspondence (Alphabetical).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of Edward Eberstadt's business correspondence, incoming and retained outgoing copies. Much of the correspondence is between Eberstadt and William R. Coe, or relates to acquisitions for the Coe collection. A small amount of William R. Coe's correspondence (letters to and from people other than Eberstadt) is interfiled.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Coe Collection of Western Americana and Other Appraisal Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of descriptions and monetary appraisals of material in the Coe Collection, chiefly at the time of donation of the material to Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under two headings: Drafts and Completed Volumes.

did.unittitle: Volume IV, Plains and Rockies, Idaho, and British Columbia Imprints
Volume V, Plains and Rockies, Idaho, and British Columbia Imprints
Volume VI, Plains and Rockies, Idaho, and British Columbia Imprints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV consists of files that document the purchase and sale of material by Edward Eberstadt's firms, as well as research carried out by employees. Files often include transcripts of manuscripts. Dates have not been supplied for the files, reflecting the fact that they are undated and may have been compiled or revised over time.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by author, subject or other main entry.

did.unittitle: Bryant, Edwin and J. Quinn Thornton

unittitle.title: National Atlas and Tuesday Morning Mail

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V consists of catalog cards and slips documenting the Coe Collection and containing descriptions of material, bibliographic information, and prices.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI consists of drafts of writings by Edward and Charles Eberstadt, and unsorted business papers, consisting chiefly of notes.
